SEC. 5. ADVISORY COMMITTEE. The President shall designate an advisory committee on engineering biology research and development with at least 12 members from various sectors to assess the progress, need for revisions, balance of activities and funding, and the effectiveness of Program priorities in maintaining US leadership in engineering biology. The Advisory Committee on engineering biology research and development will assess the Program's activities, funding, priorities, goals, management, coordination, implementation, and ethical considerations. Reports will be submitted every 3 years after the Act's enactment and at least once every 5 years thereafter to the President and the Committee. The Advisory Committee will report every 3 years on the assessment of the Program to address societal issues. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to this Committee. SEC. 6. EXTERNAL REVIEW OF ETHICAL, LEGAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND SOCIETAL ISSUES. The Director of the National Science Foundation will convene a workshop with the National Academies to review ethical, legal, environmental, and societal issues related to engineering biology research. The workshop aims to assess current research, identify gaps, and provide recommendations within 12 months of the Act's enactment. A report to Congress is due within 2 years. The Director of the National Science Foundation will transmit a summary report to Congress within 2 years after the enactment of the Act, containing findings from a workshop on ethical, legal, environmental, and societal issues related to engineering biology research. The report will evaluate research gaps and provide recommendations to address identified needs. SEC. 7. AGENCY ACTIVITIES. The National Science Foundation supports basic research at the intersection of biological, physical, and information sciences, research on environmental and social effects of engineering biology, provides research instrumentation support, and awards grants for graduate students and postdoctoral researchers.
